questions.text: You receive an email saying you won a lucky draw you never joined. What should you do?

choices.text: Reply and ask how to claim it.
Click the link to see what you won.

questions.explanation: If you didn't sign up for a contest, it's fake. Delete it.

questions.text: A scam email often tries to make you act quickly. What is this tactic called?
questions.explanation: Scammers use urgency to push you into acting without thinking.

questions.text: Which of the following is a red flag of a scam email?
questions.explanation: Legitimate companies will never ask for personal details via email.

questions.text: An email says your bank account will be frozen unless you respond immediately. What should you do first?

choices.text: Click the link in the email.
Call your bank using the official number.
Forward it to everyone for safety.

questions.explanation: Always verify with the official bank number, not the email.

questions.text: Why do scammers pretend to be well-known companies?

choices.text: To welcome you as a new customer

questions.explanation: Familiar brands make victims drop their guard.

questions.text: Which sender address looks suspicious?
questions.explanation: Scammers add extra words or fake subdomains to appear legit.

questions.text: A scammer's email often contains…
questions.explanation: Random numbers or strange words indicate fake accounts.

questions.text: Which is a safe action when unsure of a sender?

choices.text: Click the link first to check.
Open attachments to see what they are.
Reply to ask if they're real.

questions.explanation: Searching can show reports of known scam emails.

questions.text: Your friend’s account may be hacked if…

choices.text: Their email asks for urgent money help.
They send you a birthday wish.

questions.explanation: Hacked accounts often send emergency money requests.

questions.text: What is the safest first step when receiving an email from a sender you don’t recognize?
questions.explanation: Unknown senders = risk. Best to delete.

questions.text: Which link looks suspicious?
questions.explanation: Using number 1 instead of l (paypa1) is a common trick.

questions.text: A scam link often uses…
questions.explanation: Scammers hide real destinations with URL shorteners.

questions.text: Why is hovering over a link useful?

choices.text: It makes the link open automatically.
It shows the real URL at the bottom of the screen.
It sends the website your data.

questions.explanation: Hovering reveals where the link actually goes.

questions.text: A secure website usually starts with:
questions.explanation: HTTPS means encrypted connection.

questions.text: Fake login pages often look real. What’s the safest step?

choices.text: Type your password to test it.

questions.explanation: The URL is the main indicator of authenticity.

questions.text: Which attachment is MOST risky?
questions.explanation: Executable files (.exe) can contain malware.

questions.text: Your email provider warns that an attachment looks dangerous. What should you do?

choices.text: Forward the attachment to a friend.

questions.explanation: Provider warnings are there for a reason — delete.

questions.text: A scam email says your package can’t be delivered and includes a file to 'update your address.' What should you do?

choices.text: Check your real tracking app or website.

questions.explanation: Always verify with the official delivery app.

questions.text: Why are ZIP attachments dangerous?
questions.explanation: ZIP files can bundle harmful scripts.

questions.text: You receive an attachment claiming to be your 'payment receipt' but you never made a purchase. What should you do?
questions.explanation: Unsolicited payment files are often malware.
